messages.messageBody:
On Apr 21, 2004, at 10:13 AM, Doug E. Lewis wrote:

> hey guys,
>
> also, flat side of saya could rest against the body for a snug fit.  
> there were no "rules" as such, about how to carry daisho, except
> always on left side. 
certainly katana were always on the left but there were "sidearmes"
mounted for wear on the right...
Looking at the "bevel" in the picture, it doesn't appear to be anywhere
near where the sword contacts the body or another sword. I am sorry I
jumped intoo the middle of this thread it just struck me as odd,
especially when we are talking about a "pair" of swords but there is no
katana with a bevel shown. I guess I am not convinced at this point.

> Wakizashi, or uchikatana in the tachi wearing
> days, would stick out where comfortable for warrior to access.  very
> much an individual thing.  do not look at late Edo period photos for
> answer, either . 
I am looking at Sasama Yoshihiko's Dictionary of Japanese Arms and
Armour, many of the illustrations are lifted from source material of
the period you mention and they all seem to "stick out" pretty much the
same way on the left hip.

> those last samurai had never known war.  The peace
> of the Togagawa Shogunate had the unfortunate effect of diluting the
> spirit of Bushido, and causing the diminished quality of swords made,
> as well as spawning scores of schools for teaching martial arts, as
> the best teacher --- combat, war --- was reduced to duels, or
> criminal behavior. 
If war is our model then "comfort" would not be a factor, they wore
armour and a thick obi over that, they felt the weight of the swords
but not the saya. If the "bevel" was for comfort then I would expect it
to be an Edo period variant. I just have never seen a "daisho" that fit
together with a bevel, I wonder if anyone has seen an example published
anywhere?
-t

messages.messageBody:
hey guys,

also, flat side of saya could rest against the body for a snug fit.
there were no "rules" as such, about how to carry daisho, except
always on left side. Wakizashi, or uchikatana in the tachi wearing
days, would stick out where comfortable for warrior to access. very
much an individual thing. do not look at late Edo period photos for
answer, either . those last samurai had never known war. The peace
of the Togagawa Shogunate had the unfortunate effect of diluting the
spirit of Bushido, and causing the diminished quality of swords made,
as well as spawning scores of schools for teaching martial arts, as
the best teacher --- combat, war --- was reduced to duels, or
criminal behavior.

Techniques of forging were lost. The past was mythologized,
idealized. The arts flowered, but the high ranking samurai stagnated.
many low ranking samurai, often for financial reasons, became
merchants, artisans, even farmers [returning to their roots, for some]
Many of the traditions we assume were common since the Kamakura Era
were really just idealizations written down in late Shinto or
ShinShinto times [1700-1868] times as the moribund samurai of the Edo
Era tried to keep the spirit of the 1st samurai, [though they were
not called that in 670 AD] the Emperor Temmu, alive.

doug e

messages.messageBody:
I am not sure that carrying the sword in one hand or the other is the
issue, here. They were always worn on the left side, the Japan sort of
frowned on left handedness (I hope that is a real word). Anyway, the
daisho pair would not be worn on the right side of your body.

Bob

I think there is some confusion with 'Sekibun' and 'Akabumi', these are
alternative readings of the same two kanji, it is now commonly read
'Sekibun', perhaps the item is signed 'Yurakusai Sekibun' which is his
common signature and is very hard to read due to his odd way of cutting it.
Alan

messages.msgSnippet: Jim, Digging up an old post here as I ve got some additional info from Steve Smith fittings expert from Liverpool Museum & British Northern Token Society.
messages.messageBody:
Jim,

Digging up an old post here as I've got some additional info from Steve
Smith fittings expert from Liverpool Museum & British Northern Token
Society.

http://www.c.farrar.btinternet.co.uk/wak/

The mounts are the work of Sekibun Akabumi or his brother of the same name.
Mid 19th Century. Liverpool Museum has mounts of identical type in its
inventory.

The mystery of the beveled saya has also now been answered by Steve. The
bevel is because the Wak was part of a daisho the katana would also have a
bevel so the two sit tightly together in the belt. This also confirms the
blade was carried by a Samurai!

http://www.c.farrar.btinternet.co.uk/wak/Dscf0073.jpg

Peter

_____

From: Jim Gilbert [mailto:jggilbert@...]
Sent: 12 March 2004 03:49
To: nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com
Subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Wakizashi Help

Peter,
The original metal fittings appear to be a set by one maker or at least a
single workshop. I think that they could be work from Shonai in northern
Honshu. Is the fuchi or tsuba signed? The kozuka is a later substitution
of lower quality. I can't really see the menuki in the photos. The kashira
appears to be of a different material. I'm guessing that it may have been
lost and that the tsuka has been rewrapped, but I can't see much in the
photos.

The bevel on the saya would be up against the body when the sword was worn
so it's probably not just for show. My guess is that it might be more
comfortable to wear or would help position it somehow (?). It's an unusual
feature. Does anyone know what it's called or what it is really for?

As a lone wakizashi it could have been worn by a non-samurai, but I don't
see anything about the koshirae that would make that necessarily so.

Jim

messages.messageBody:
Peter,
FWIW, there's a wakizashi in this week's sale at Christie's that is mounted with a "beveled" saya similar to yours (and mixed nanban-style fittings that are not like yours).

Also, I ran across a tsuba somewhat like yours in the Haynes auction catalog # 6, lot 208 with a signature in sosho style that looks like the style of writing used by the Shonai Sekibun makers. Haynes translates it as Jusai.

Jim





The blade has been cut down by several inches, so unfortunately any
signature it once had is gone.
A few people I have showed the sword to have commented on the
unusual saya bevel.



Thanks,

Peter

messages.subject: Re: Wakizashi Help
messages.msgSnippet: Jim, Thank you for your reply. Unfortunately the tsuba and fuchi are not signed. The kashira is lost and has been replaced with a polished horn one. The menuki
messages.messageBody:
Jim,

Thank you for your reply.

Unfortunately the tsuba and fuchi are not signed. The kashira is
lost and has been replaced with a polished horn one. The menuki are
matching good quality shakudo with gilding, catfish and plants
design.

The blade has been cut down by several inches, so unfortunately any
signature it once had is gone.
A few people I have showed the sword to have commented on the
unusual saya bevel.

I was told by a dealer that from the style of the sword it wouldn't
have been part of a daisho. Interestingly enough it also appears to
have battle damage on the back of the mune.

Thanks,

Peter
